results.title: You Can't Say That
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Oh! The problems of censorship! John Baxter shows, from the days of seemingly innocuous material such as the Keystone Cops to the present, that there have been recurrent problems with Censorship boards. This program, part of a ten part documentary, Filmstruck, considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: Muscle: dynamics of contraction
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program. Unit 4. Physiology”.
The many hundreds of muscles in the human body differ greatly with respect to the speeds at which they shorten. They can be divided into three major categories: smooth, cardiac and skeletal. In this film these three types are defined, and elaborate apparatus is used to reveal that the contractile properties of a whole muscle can be explained in terms of the properties of the single muscle cell.

results.title: Chinese Diggers
results.creator_credit: Teck Tan, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
A Prizewinner at the 31st International Film and TV Festival of New York this program looks at Australia’s attitude to Chinese Australians who wanted to join the Armed Forces to assist in the defence of Australia during the Second World War. In examining the stories of those interviewed a number of issues are brought to light. The video is accompanied by Teacher’s notes and workcards.

results.title: Going It Alone
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Filmmaking has never really been studio based. John Baxter, well known Australian film historian and cinema critic, interviews some of the independents. He also takes a look at the Disney animation studio in Burbank, as well as showing us rare footage of a surrealist “Snow White” starring Betty Boop. this program is the final episode in the “Filmstruck” series which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: Waves, beaches & coasts
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 24 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Looks at the motion of water particles in a passing wave and how waves are generated by wind. The power of waves shape coastal areas such as bays and headlands. Problems with dredging and the building of sea walls are discussed as well as the creation and effect of devastating seismic waves which result from earthquakes under the sea and on the land.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television

results.title: Glaciers
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 23 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Presents the properties of glaciers and assesses their importance in sculpting Earth’s surface. The study of glacial movement is important in determining the impact of the Greenhouse Effect. By studying the cyclic nature of Ice Ages, geologists can assist scientists in predicting rising sea levels. There are two types of glaciers; valley glaciers which move from mountains down to valleys and continental glaciers which are single giant ice sheets which accumulate in doems on the surface of the planet.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television

results.title: Switzerland/Texas
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Filming in Australia has been described as “Switzerland wanting to go to Texas”. In this program, John Baxter, well-known Australian film historian and cinema critic, looks at the state of the Australian film industry. This is part five of a ten part documentary “Filmstruck” which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: Hungry Ghosts
results.creator_credit: Zi Zhong Wang, Barbara Mariotti and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
During Adelaide’s Chinese cultural week in 1988 a group of puppeteers from Adelaide’s sister city of Penang were invited to present one of their plays in honour of the Festival of Hungry Ghosts which fell at this time. The program shows their ritualistic preparations and some of the other festivities which took place.

results.title: Wind, dust & deserts
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 22 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Geologists classify deserts as areas with infrequent precipitation so a diversity of formations from Antartica to the Sahara exist as desert landscapes. Movement of the earth and the sun and the roles of wind and rain shadow in the increasing desertification of the planet is examined. Movement of features such as sand dunes has seen an increase in the vastness of deserts and their movement across the surface of the planet.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
